number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Highly recommended. Maybe the best racing game on Linux. If you ever wanted to race with a futuristic car in a very futuristic world, this game is for you! Its racing with a twist, your car can perform various new functions such as jumping, wallriding and even flying! All this makes for very interesting race courses where the quickest way sometimes requires a lot of creativity. Something like extreme-G mixed with Trackmania.Graphics and sound are excellent, but my favourite part is the gameplay. The car really controls so well, it is even possible to play with the keyboard. Good control is important as the game requires lighting fast reactions.Note there are no AI oponents, hopefully this is something that will be added later. I had a lot of fun playing with random people through multiplayer though. The split screen option is also a very welcome addition and this can very easily be a fun game to play when having friends over. Just make sure to find an easy level pack first as most of the default levels take a lot of practice to master.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hi! I'm Andrew, a long time veteran from Nitronic Rush. I played it a ton when it first came out!! Loved it! I've also speedran it and enjoyed the heck out of it. The optimization in the tenths of a second on community and story levels in Nitronic Rush gives me a great satisfaction.Distance surprised me at first and the controls were slightly different, a little more clunkier. However I had a very positive transfer effect that I immediately noticed when I first started playing. I was also very accustomed to the controls, thruster boosting, and flying.Positives:- Incredible interaction with the developers, almost immediate and positive feedback. Bug reports are addressed very quickly.- Promotional events consistently every Saturday, tournaments occasionally- Updates are constant and positively improve the game each time. Features are added onto and changes make a lot of sense with development, user experience, and overall gameplay design.- Fun single, and online multiplayer experience.- Great solo experience that offers improving your times, finding skips, and optimization in movement of the car- Game modes are plentiful and offer a lot more gameplay time and hours into the game in addition to Adventure mode, community levels, and multiplayer racing.- Fast, quick reaction time, and game sense is awarded to avoid obstacles and finding faster ways to complete the track. This allows you to leave your opponents in the dust and gives you a slight advantage.Overall, I feel distance is a solid 9/10 for me at the moment even in its current state! :) The developers have already mentioned that they will be still improving and refining the game even after release. They also are working on completing Adventure Mode for next year in 2016 and getting the game out of Early Access. I've already recommended it to many friends and many of them enjoy the game for what it offers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Aside from the unfinished adventure mode, this game is looking fantastic. The mechanics are pretty much completely solid for a modern and physics-driven, yet arcade-y car game, a lot like Rush. Especially Rush 2049. You guys remember that, right? Well, that's immediately what the wings reminded me of, although you have a Spy Hunter-esque turbo which doubles as a jet engine in Wing mode.The other amzing thing was the procedural damage to your vehicle's model.I don't know if it's really being torn in half or if it's just for looks, and the whole model is still there, but the fact it even knows what part of the car to disapear is still fantastic. You also regenerate less serious damage like having a laser graze the side or top of your car. And even if you take serious damage, you can still go for a regen checkpoint. I've survived with like a third of a car left. IDK how, but okay. Typically crashing will kill you faster than lasers, but it they do destroy your ability to move, and then you'll probably crash into something, like a grinder.EDIT: Lasers generate heat and can kill you with that. Also, Torcht (composer and dev) demonstrated that you can survive with a sliver of your car left as long as its got wheels.I also like the mix of predictability and unpredictablity of various hazards, including non-static hazards that follow you before deploying. Protip: you can cheese them by slowing down.The campaign pulls off proper progression of both difficulty and music in spades. The first time you encounter the anomaly  it comes all sudden, the music is ♥♥♥♥in creepy, and there's not much change in diffiuclty but still leaves you like "OHHHH♥♥♥♥♥♥" but then when you encounter it again, the music is more rhythmic, like "I've dealt with this before come at me, scrub," while the maps are much harder.And the ending you get because the adventure mode is incomplete was incredible. I've never seen anything like it, and mostly because at first I thought it was actually part of the game, and something crazy was about to go down. Hopefully this same, crazy bug-out becomes a part of the story at some point, a lot like how the anomalies work.btw, what the ♥♥♥♥ was that detour? That was a wild experience.Silence. No gravity. No heat buildup. Bruh.I would love to see more of these mind♥♥♥♥eries in the campaign, and be a part of the story somehow as well.If you need any pointers, I'm sure Ransom Arceihn would know what to do.No, I'm not even going to comment on the graphics because they speak for themselves, although I will say it's fantastically optimized, and I get ~60 frames running FXAA3, medium reflection, full anastropic, and medium shadows, all on an old, 2010 video card from when DX11 was first supported. Oh, and my motherboard is a♥♥♥♥♥♥and has bad timings (constant RAM addressing errors). Really need to get a new one. The only other game that can hold it's own despite that is Star Conflict.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Distance is incredibly satisfying. It feels like Wipeout 2048, Burnout, and Trackmania had a strange love child. Yet somehow, Distance manages to be something all it's own.If you're a fan of over the top racing games or the arcade racers of the early 2000's, you'll absolutely love this game. The levels created by the developer are well thought out and look incredible, and the large number of fan made levels are quality from what I've played thus far. Refract does a great job integrating fan made levels into the different online and offline modes. Distance nails that neo techno vibe that looks equal parts Tron and Amplitude. The levels also pulse along with the music, which is a nice touch.There is something viscerally satisfying about the controls. A huge component of Distance is mastering how to "jump" from one piece of track to the next. Tilting the car, and learning how to work the controls is a fun uphill battle. I've played many games in this genre, and none of them handle the way Distance does. There is also the way the car starts to fall apart in between checkpoints. The sense of speed gives me flashbacks of F Zero, but the arcade style controls are much more remeniscent of Trackmania and Wipeout.If there was one criticism to be had for Distance's controls, it's that the drifting mechanic doesn't feel right. You don't really need to drift because of how the game works, but my brain is so programmed to from years of playing racing games. It feels like the game registers any attempt to drift at any speed as the same thing, which is a little frustrating. Also, I think Distance would really benefit from a "bump left" and "bump right" function. The game feels a lot like Wipeout to me, and without the ability to double tap to move out of the way of an obstacle, something just feels a little off.This is all nitpicking though. Distance is a phenomanal game. If you love time attack or arcade racers, I highly recommend picking this up. It's the best early access game I've ever played, and probably the best racer to ever come out of early access. This game will only get better over time. Better to pick it up now than when it's $40 or $60 in a year. It's worth every penny.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is great. I can't say too much about it as I haven't played a lot, but from the time I have played, I've really enjoyed it. Here are some pros and cons to the game:Pros:  - The music is really nice. If you're into any sort of electronic music, the game has some decent songs in store. If you don't enjoy the songs the game provides, it's simple to choose your own songs from your computer - Good levels. The levels are fun, fast-paced and keep you on the ball constantly. It's easy to get caught up playing many different levels without realising where the time has gone - Fast-paced. This game is incredibly fast-paced. Every single second counts and misjudging a jump, a turn or an obstacle can be very problematic. This makes it very fun as the level of focus required is great. - The community. The community is constantly creating new levels and this provides all kinds of fun, with new designs constantly coming out - You can create your own levels. If you want a break from the action, you can create your own levels to submit to the steam workshop for you and other people to play. Cons: - The design capabilties of the cars isn't too expansive, but the design of the car doesn't really matter, but for those who like cosmetics, this may be somewhat annoyingOverall, this game is really good, and I'd recommend buying it in a sale as the price is a little much. But regardless, this game is fantastic, intriuging and fun to play always.9.5/10

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have to give out my review to this, I hope Refract will read this.I played the earlier version of this game, Nitronic Rush, and seeing how much they've improved I had to by this version and support it. For a game in progress - It was absolutely worth it.I had so much fun sitting hours and hours, playing community levels, playing on online servers, just flying around in my car, doing very fast sprint levels with style and I really enjoyed the atmosphere of every level. This is the core of this game and it was very succesful, and I believe this is going to be a great game. Besides... this one thing.Playing all of those community made levels really made me want to make one of my own. The level editor is probably the most confusing editor I've seen in a while, even after the tutorial it took me a lot of time to position things correctly - like checkpoints or particles. Sometimes they don't spawn where you put the cursor if you build too high, other times it just takes years to position them right. Just like the teleporters - it took me ages to understand how they work, and how to position them right.Refract studios, you have an incredible game and an amazing idea, but you have to help us keep expanding it. There must be ways where we could make this editor more simple and more explanatory (If that's even a word) . I'm up for giving any suggestion you may need.Thank you for making such an awesome game.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								May not be the racing game you've been looking for to put years of commitment into, but, at the same time, it is. Believe it when it says "Survival Racing". I can't wait to see more of this game. Great concept, amazing execution, loads of content thanks to the in game level creator, and plenty of overall content to keep you coming back somewhat consistently at the least. The best game I could compare it to would be San Francisco Rush 2049, Cruisin Exotica/USA, or even Hydro Thunder. It is absolutely amazing, even if you're not into racing games, this is one you could really sink time into.To play the game, all you need to do is play the tutorial and pay attention. To win, you need patience. There is no learning curve to this game; it is a cliff. You just have to throw yourself off the edge over and over again until you learn where the pull chord is, only to drift into lava or get grabbed by a passing airplanes turbine. Even so, it is fun in its own right.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Distance is a wonderful racing game.  The second game by the developers following Nitronic Rush.  This game is amazing in so many ways.  From the high speeds you can reach, to the tricks and stunts you can perform and the different game modes.  There is an incredibly detailed and awesome level editor, while the TrackMania series has the title for level editors, this game definetely is up there, with the ability to change light and colour of track pieces and the amount of scenery objects that can be placed.  When I play this game, I am constantly being remminded of Trackmania and how the cars felt when climbing up steep ramps and walls.  This game takes it further by adding in a jump feature allowing for some awesome manoeuvring over gaps and jumping from wall to wall like a car ninja.  For an early access, this is definetely something amazing.  We can all expect that this wil continue to get better with each update.  This is a game I would easily reccommend if they liked the TrackMania series cause they would almost feel right at home.  While anyone who has a fancy would enjoy it, TrackMania players would probably start off better.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you came here to check the reviews to see if the game is worth it. You have your answer.Just scroll down and look at all these happy people.Over 90% of people have recommended this game.Why are you still looking at reviews.Why are you still thinking about it?Why are you on your computer when you could be outside enjoying nature?Oh, wait. I think I know the answer to that one. Because games like this are fun, and the outdoors isn't a NEON FUTURE CITY WITH FLYING MAGNET CARS. At least, not yet.While we wait for that time to come. Just play this. Oh? Don't wanna spend $20 yet? Still want to mull it over? Look up "Nightronic Rush" on the internet and play that. It's a game about a neon future city with flying magnet cars. Sounds familiar right? Because Distance is kind of a more polished "Sequel" of Nightronic Rush. Same guys, same concept, much more polished. Much prettier. Yes.Now, to be serious for a moment. If you like what you see. It feels as cool as you can probably imagine. It doesn't get dull.The only time it gets dull is when you start to memorize a track too well. So? Download a bunch on Steam Workshop. There's like 5 more tracks every week.Some of these tracks will suck and I still don't know how to get rid of those ones. But most of them are pretty good. Hopefully the devs add a way to manage tracks and make playlists of tracks.That being my only gripe about this. Download it. Enjoy it. And if you're playing on a gamepad? Assign boost and jump to your bumpers. Trust me.Have fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I loved the previous game by this team, Nitronic Rush. But there was something I didn't like about it: Nitronic Rush had a lot of side content that got very, very difficult. Thankfully, it was pushed off to the side, in a place where only the the craziest players could challenge themselves. You could play Nitronic Rush's campaign and face some tough-but-fair levels in crazy, beautiful neon cyber future environments.Distance doesn't give you that option. It bills itself as a "racing survival" game, so by the time you reach about halfway through what currently exists in its singleplayer, Distance's "Adventure" mode starts dishing out masochistic levels that delight on taking away your fun abilities and (sometimes literally) putting your car through a meat grinder. The game frequently teaches you how to do something, and while demonstrating how to use it, you're expected to learn something brand new before you're comfortable with the previous ability. It's frustrating and a little overwhelming. It's everything I didn't like about Nitronic Rush's extended content. I'm still recommending it, however. It's still more of what I wanted, and when the game isn't being unrelentingly masochistic, it's still terrific fun (particularly if you dive in to the Steam Workshop for a better selection of tracks). The only thing I miss is Nitronic Rush's sense of humor -- Distance is a bit more self-serious, which is a minor bummer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								Really fun, good artstyle (reminds me of TRON), good music. Has a sort of "WipEout" vibe to it. It'll be interesting to see where this game goes when more is added to it, but as early access/beta/whatever games go, this is a solid one.Only slight annoyances are the flying controls and the WASD booster things, they just feel a bit wonky (you have to operate and think about too many things at once, also the camera points itself in unhelpful directions while this is happening) and interrupt the smooth speed of the ground segments.The Steam workshop functionality is well-integrated, meaning it's easy to play new community-created maps all the time, and even create your own. There's also online multiplayer which is pretty fun.EDIT: It seems as though the most popular online maps are "parkour" ones which involve awkward mid-air maneuvering and tricky jumps, as opposed to speedy racing. I can't say I like these parkour tracks very much - they usually involve repeatedly failing a certain segment before moving on to the next one and repeating that process until the end, but even so, the online is still fun, and the community maps can be quite creative.Overall if you like racing games, futuristic stuff and DnB, this is probably a game for you.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Wake me when the online connectivity improves." The story of an Australian and his American friend.Kidding. While I would like to write out a short story on that, it's just a case of this game still being early in development. What's there is already great, and you're buying what's advertised. Flashy neon graphics that make me feel like I'm playing a GOOD Tron game, if one ever existed. A snappy electronic soundtrack to go with it. Gameplay that needs reflexes just as quick as the car you're driving (exaggerating just a bit, it's actually very forgiving but you'll need to be good with your reactions, because once or twice the game throws an obstacle in your face like a friend tossing a basketball at your face and shouting 'think fast'.)All in all, fun, but STILL IN PROGRESS. The single player is short, but we are told this is because it is incomplete, simple as that. Even then, the developers tell us that they want the campaign to be short, so if there's not meant to be much more beyond that, then likely the game will focus on user generated content (rather interesting level editor and steam workshop support! The editor may be difficult to grasp, not out of difficulty, but out of the sheer amount of options) AND its online mode.Which leads me to the next thing to talk about. Upon selecting the online arcade, the game tests your network capability. Both me and my American friend were told our networks weren't too great (limited connectivity to NAT servers), and his works eith every game imaginable. Clearing up a few ports to host a server is one thing, but being unable to connect to any server at all is another. If we knew which ports or remedies would solve the Network Capability test, then we'd be having a blast. Until then, we can't connect to any servers whatsoever. So beware of this if you're buying the game with a focus on its online.Until it gets fixed, I'll have to shelf this for now. Great game! Can't wait until it improves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Racing games usually aren't my thing, but Distance does to racing what a mescaline overdose does to an adolescent polar bear.It's one of the trippiest cyber-punk dystopia racing games i've ever seen, with an awesome soundtrack to boot!The game runs quite nicely, and that's usually because the game does not have an over-abundance of clutter, just buildings and racing hazards.There are several different gamemodes to choose from, but my favorite is sprint, where you have to finish the track as fast as you can.The game will send you into spirals, climbing up walls, and flying. Yes, flying, not the kind of flying where you are in the air for a period of time and then land but....wait that is flying, anyways, your car doors turn into "wings" and you go "whoosh!"And yes, you can race against other people.Keep in mind that it is still in early access, and the adventure mode is still not complete, so there are still some tracks that have not yet been released by the devs.But if you're itching for more tracks, don't fret, because this game comes with a very detailed map maker!Already the steam workshop has tons of player-made maps that you can play on-- most of them quite good.So rev up your engines and get ready to go the Distance!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game. Wow. I can barely put it into words but if i had to they would be - Colourful, Fast, Smooth, Beautiful, Epic, Flying, Racing, and Chaos. This game is made by the same students that made Nitronic Rush at Digipen Institute of Technology, I got the original Nitronic Rush off of the Digipen website after a student visited my school a few years ago, and I LOVED IT. Now that the students have made their own studio - Refract - they have made a more, polished version of the old game. Playing this game always gives a a rush of adrenaline, and a smile on my face, and with multiplayer, and worshop racetracks, what's not to love?!P.S. - One of the BEST Early Acess Steam games EVER.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								So a note before this review, at points I'm going to reference "Nitronic Rush" which is the previous game that the devs created and it's pretty much an alpha of this game.  (Even though I call it an alpha, it was well enough to be one of my favorite games) Let's begin (TL;DR version at end)Graphics: -In general: The graphics are very nice. And the options on the graphics are very nice as well, letting you customize them to a good extent which should make this playable on most machines.  -In game: The levels have very contrasting colors and a good variety of them in levels making it fun to see what's next.  The timer, speed, and boost gauge are on the vehicle, which works even though it might seem like it wouldn't.  I have not tried out the custom music option yet, which is supposed to change the graphics even more in time with your music (which actually sounds really cool).Performance:-For some reason and I don't know why, this game seems a little slow to me. I have put my graphics to a good spot, but it still seems just a bit slow. I am comparing to nitro in this case, and I'm not sure if it's because of a new engine or some other factor, might even just be me, but it does seem like it runs slightly slow with the graphics settings on par with nitro.( I have been informed that the future builds are going to be more stable, and that the slowness is due to added physics and sensitivity changes)The Gameplay:-This is a survival racer, not a standard racer. Most levels have you going through a level past numerous obstacles, lasers, and more to get to the goal. Compared to nitro rush I have to say that Distance really upped the gameplay. Lasers don't kill you now, instead they slice apart your car into a bunch of tiny pieces which is actually really fun to mess with. The flying is utilized a LOT more, in much more entertaining ways. Certain areas disable the wings so you can't cheat through them which utilizes more skill. Enemies do actually change depending on how you move (one actually stopped me for a whole minute because it kept tracking me). There was even a spot with zero gravity and I can't emphasize how much I actually enjoyed this area. It's something unique and I haven't seen something like that in a racing game before. I'd really like much more of that area in the game. The levels at times are confusing, and I got lost at at least one point.  All in all, just from playing the adventure mode, I can say that this is quite the improvement to Nitro.-The only thing I'd actually suggest for an improvement is having more wall riding and ceiling riding areas similar to hardcore mode from nitro. Those are a lot of fun to drive withControls:-Controls are pretty good, not as sensitive as I'd like standard, but overall good. I have learned you can customize the controls and fix them to however you like. (I would not overly reccomend customizing the controls, but it's more of a personal choice.)Level Editor:-This thing... this thing is... amazing. I haven't seen a more customizable level editor. It looks very much like a full 3D modeling program. I thought you could add custom models, but apparently the maps so far have been using the in-game items which is very nice. Here's an idea, someone make a drivable map on a heavy from TF2. Overall it is a little intimidating to newcomers, but it should be fun to use and it is very cool.All in all, I really enjoyed playing this game so far and it's not even fully released yet. Once it's fully released, the bugs should be fixed (there aren't that many bugs to begin with) and there should be some new features to play around with.I have learned there is a car color customizer in the options. I do highly reccomend this game, and it's not even fully released yet. I look forward to the full release of this game.Thanks to Californ1a for giving me some info to make the review better and clarifying some things I mispoke on.TL;DR: Flippy car game with lasers, booms, flying and more. 10/10 would race

Early Access Review
								A very abstract-yet-addicting approach to merging both puzzle and driving genres into one new-age racing game.rundown:+ amazingly crisp graphics+ an easy-to-learn level workshop editor with plenty of tutorials+ A catchy futuristic electronic soundtrack+ no HUD to block your view (for this kind of game, all you really need is a speed gauge and elapsed time)+ Your car can freakin' fly/flip/rotate/glide!!!+ Nice visual damage detailing to your vehicle. (from small dents in your fender to being sliced in half by lasers)+ You can still continue driving, even with your car diced up in half, as long as you have more than half of your car is intact!- Car runs somewhat slow without boost and turns/flips over on a dime- Only one car for the whole game (although it could be a positive thing for people who dislike complicated racing games) - If you're a racing fan, why are you still reading this? GO BUY IT ALREADY!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								The more i play distance, the more i feel like it could be THE racing game to pick up. and for an early access title it sure as heck is more polished than other games that share space there.the gist of it is summed up by the trailer and the game's description: you drive a super cool tron car of sorts through various areas in an attempt to get from point a to point b as fast as possible, while trying not to get sliced, smashed, flung off, or nitronic crash into a wall. the latter is silly because you can also drive on walls and cielings, which counts as a stunt (more on that later). you can also fly, but later levels tend to flip flop between letting you fly and not letting you fly, and you can shave seconds off the flying areas if you know how to.and that isn't all. you can cool down your thrusters by doing stunts. don't ask how it works, just roll with it. the controls feel buttery smooth and responsive, though some community made levels will make you think otherwise at times. the music in the game is top notch and i'd gladly toss my cash at Refract or Torcht just to get it through steam.and while the adventure is short and sweet, the replayability comes from the workshop. seriously, go check it out. there's dozens of tracks waiting to be conquered, either alone or in competition with friends and strangers alike. there's  the Stunt mode for those who want to do flips and stuff, or if you want to put it to more use on the courses, Speed and Style is a mode about doing tricks to cut time off the clock. finally, for the ultimate in keepaway, look no further than Reverse Tag. that assumes there's folks hosting that mode, which is often rare. but when it is hosted, it's the perfect blend of sprint, stunt, and king of the hill, with the hill being a ball of sorts that you snag and take with you, but others can also easily snag off you by driving into the ball while you have it.and if you intend to play this on multiplayer, be sure to hop on Distance on Saturdays. correct me if i'm wrong but i think that's the day when folks go outta thier way to host games of Distance multiplayer.EDIT:Californ1a Sep 3, 2015 @ 8:16pm  Yup, every Saturday 2pm-4pm eastern time is our community multiplayer event: http://steamcommunity.com/app/233610/discussions/0/528398719786414266/Pinning this comment to the review. speedy saturdays is a thing, okay?also, figured i'd update this with some developments.Distance now has a Grip button (think Sonic's stomp in later games, but clings to walls and cielings if your wheels are pointed toward them, and slower, and also acts as the increased handling button) and has toned down a certain bug that allowed huge level skipping to the point it could be outright unfun. the trick is still doable, but now it's not capable of skipping entire sections of track.but the biggest improvement is the editor, which is now capable of more things than ever before. you need only look at "Uncanny Valley" for a decent start. granted, it could do that stuff before, but it was limited back then.on a side note, community is active enough that if you DL a map or two via workshop every now and then, you could get a good amount of maps to race on.TL:DR: Distance is a racing game all about going fast, and surviving. loads of community content keep the game fresh enough to last a while, and devs are hard workers, keeping the progress going.EDIT: if you see this review by any chance and get the game, hop onto the discord channel.this also applies to anybody who already owns the game. it's the best way to keep on top of Speedy Saturdays and community events, as well as the community showing off tidbits of what they are working on with the game's editor.oh, and the main levels of the game look like they're going to get prettied up when the adventure mode gets updated content.RIP Broken Symetry, though.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've had a DK2 for over a year now, and have played just about every worthwhile VR game currently available.  Out of nowhere, Distance is suddenly my favourite VR experience.Not only is it a really unique game in itself, like a cross between Radial-G and Mirror's Edge, but it has a seriously sweet soundtrack (especially love the transition to spacey ambient when your craft enters the zero-G bits, the kick drum thumping back in as you hit gravity again).  It's also the perfect game for VR:  the cockpit provides a wide view not only ahead of you, but beneath you thanks to a glass window in the floor that you'll be using a lot more than you might think.  Like Radial-G, you'll also find yourself looking up through the glass above you to see where the track vertically twists and turns in three dimensions.Runs like a dream (a rare but essential thing for VR games), plays awesomely.  Adventure mode will have you laughing and screaming, and has an unexpected sense of terror similar to SUPERHOT's story mode.  If you have a DK2, this is a must buy.

								This Distance is a fast and intense action survival racing game, where you drive agens other unique players in advanced atmospheric worlds.Have you ever wanted to be in that Tron legacy world with laser, future and amazing cool music? Well, here is your chance to live it in a car and do alot of driving, jumping, spinning, flying, avoiding insane traps and tracks. content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'd honestly say this is one of the most entertaining racing games I've ever played. There's definitely not many games that require you to jump from wall to wall at high speeds while avoiding traps like lasers and saws while listening to fitting music before you've even completed the tutorial. Also the visuals look awesome, but it's not so overdone that you can't figure out what's going on.It's one of those rare games where you can join a server, find one of the best players in the entire game, and still enjoy yourself.To get the most out of it you'll need to play the community levels, since there's not many official levels. It's not a problem though, since a lot of community levels are on par with the official ones, and some are even better (plus the files are usually less than 1mb, so having hundreds of levels downloaded barely takes up any space).Anyway, here's a quick summary:+Looks and feels awesome+Challenging but not frustrating+Music fits perfectly+Hundreds of quality community levels+Procedural track generation (very early stages so will get a lot better)+Doesn't get annoying if you keep failing+Gravity doesn't even matter as long as you're going fast enough+Improved enough from Nitronic Rush to justify buying-Still no AI/ghosts (they'll probably be coming soon, but offline is a little lonely currently)-Some of the dynamic obsticles can feel luck based, which gets annoying if you're going for a fast time-Possibly a little harder to get good at if you have no controller

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok, before you buy this game, go play Nitronic Rush. If you like that you will like this. Distance is a Tron-esqe racing game where you speed along floating roads and fly through obstacles at very high speeds.Gameplay-10/10The gameplay in Distance is absolutely flawless. The controls feel fluid and are very responsive, and I know that I am in control of my car at all times. The gameplay consists of driving along roads at high speeds while dodging obstacles like buzzsaws, lasers, walls, spinning cylinders of death spikes, and so on. While you usually just drive along roads, you also can fly. Everything about the driving and flying is great. There is also a boost system that reminds me of Excite Truck, which was my favorite racing game until I got Distance. Also, if you get cut by lasers, you can still drive with half of your car. That's probably my favorite thing in Distance.Story-N/AThe adventure mode isn't finished yet, so I can't really review it right now.Multiplayer-10/10I haven't encountered any lag in multiplayer yet. You have to get to the finish as fast as possible, trying to beat the other players. However, the other players appear as ghosts and cannot effect your vehicle, making the race into more of a synonomous time trial. Graphics-10/10The graphics remind me of Nitronic Rush, but have a glossy new feel that fits with the atmosphere very well. Overall-10/10For what it is, Distance is a fantastic game. Even though it is essentially a remake of Nitronic Rush, it does everything right. It runs well on lower spec PCs, you can play it on Mac and Linux as well as PC, there's a level editor with workshop support. Just keep in mind that it is a racing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Gameplay-wise, the game is less about racing, more about finishing levels as fast as possible. There's a difference. The base levels are excellent, the learning curve is easy, and the community made levels range from terrible to amazing with the majority (in my opinion) being amazing. More often than not, you'll be driving through these levels and resetting the entire race from the beginning if you die once, as most high score badges involve perfect runs. Oddly enough, I found this game almost as relaxing as Euro Truck Simulator. Almost.Visually, this game is very appealing to me. Think Tron. There's an in-game option of adding your own playlist which literally involves just linking a folder on your C:/ drive so the game can access the path, which I think is priceless. The base story mode can be done in an hour, so if  you want to get the most out of this game, check out the community made levels and the soundtrack the level-makers provide. Aside from that, the sandbox level editor is confusing to me (as all level editors are, I'm just not of the right mind for them) but it seems easy enough for other people to make some really beautiful levels.Improvements? I think this game has an excellent concept and would love to see up to 4-person local co-op, but I can only dream of a day there were more mass local co-op in many other games. I think the online servers could be improved by establishing P2P servers instead of player hostings for the sake of consistency and ease of use. Last, I think there should be a lap-based mode for legitimate racing as it would draw a more competitive crowd to this game, would mitigate the severity of dying, and would further promote the use of the car tricks to get ahead of other players via boosting (because I get the feeling items, like in Kart racing games, will not be added at this stage of development).Come to think of it, if this game had a mode that functioned like a Mario Kart game for the sake of lap or single stretch racing, but kept the gameplay mechanics and visuals as-is, I'd♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants and proceed to buy a 4-pack.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I loved the previous game by this team, Nitronic Rush. But there was something I didn't like about it: Nitronic Rush had a lot of side content that got very, very difficult. Thankfully, it was pushed off to the side, in a place where only the the craziest players could challenge themselves. You could play Nitronic Rush's campaign and face some tough-but-fair levels in crazy, beautiful neon cyber future environments.Distance doesn't give you that option. It bills itself as a "racing survival" game, so by the time you reach about halfway through what currently exists in its singleplayer, Distance's "Adventure" mode starts dishing out masochistic levels that delight on taking away your fun abilities and (sometimes literally) putting your car through a meat grinder. The game frequently teaches you how to do something, and while demonstrating how to use it, you're expected to learn something brand new before you're comfortable with the previous ability. It's frustrating and a little overwhelming. It's everything I didn't like about Nitronic Rush's extended content. I'm still recommending it, however. It's still more of what I wanted, and when the game isn't being unrelentingly masochistic, it's still terrific fun (particularly if you dive in to the Steam Workshop for a better selection of tracks). The only thing I miss is Nitronic Rush's sense of humor -- Distance is a bit more self-serious, which is a minor bummer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Wake me when the online connectivity improves." The story of an Australian and his American friend.Kidding. While I would like to write out a short story on that, it's just a case of this game still being early in development. What's there is already great, and you're buying what's advertised. Flashy neon graphics that make me feel like I'm playing a GOOD Tron game, if one ever existed. A snappy electronic soundtrack to go with it. Gameplay that needs reflexes just as quick as the car you're driving (exaggerating just a bit, it's actually very forgiving but you'll need to be good with your reactions, because once or twice the game throws an obstacle in your face like a friend tossing a basketball at your face and shouting 'think fast'.)All in all, fun, but STILL IN PROGRESS. The single player is short, but we are told this is because it is incomplete, simple as that. Even then, the developers tell us that they want the campaign to be short, so if there's not meant to be much more beyond that, then likely the game will focus on user generated content (rather interesting level editor and steam workshop support! The editor may be difficult to grasp, not out of difficulty, but out of the sheer amount of options) AND its online mode.Which leads me to the next thing to talk about. Upon selecting the online arcade, the game tests your network capability. Both me and my American friend were told our networks weren't too great (limited connectivity to NAT servers), and his works eith every game imaginable. Clearing up a few ports to host a server is one thing, but being unable to connect to any server at all is another. If we knew which ports or remedies would solve the Network Capability test, then we'd be having a blast. Until then, we can't connect to any servers whatsoever. So beware of this if you're buying the game with a focus on its online.Until it gets fixed, I'll have to shelf this for now. Great game! Can't wait until it improves.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game really shines when the courses are putting you through the paces.  Driving at breakneck speeds as you jump from wall to wall, dodging obstacles and lasers as they appear in front of you, Distance is amasing.  The only bad part of the game (at present, dont know how it will change in the future) is the flying.  It lacks the speed and tension of the driving with few obstacles and no real precision required.  Put in some tight corridors and im sure thatll change, but for now its a bit lackluster.  These sections are, however, few and far between generally so they dont really hurt the game.Be warned, the keyboard controls are a bit nuts (ya, im the guy that trys to play driving games with a keyboard) with way too many inputs to mange.  Fortunately, this is easily solved with a controller (havent felt a difference that big since Dark Souls).EDIT: I think ive figured out why i like this game so much.  Its very much like what a 3d Sonic game should be, platforming and all.  good on you devs, good on you.

								This arcade racer has beauty, control, stunts, and is gravity defying in all the right ways.  Highly recommended on sale for fans of arcade racing games or speedrunners. Other people should consider waiting to get it until closer to release unless they have friends to play this with. Adventure mode serves as a pretty good tutorial that covers all the major mechanics even though its still being developed. The meat of this game are the workshop and generative levels. Online mode is decent, but the other player cars are basically live ghosts, so don't expect car smashing here.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Story: 5/10 - So far in this game, the story consists of single levels which individually teach you how to use your controls. These levels are fun, but there are few of them and they finish rather quickly which makes the game repetitive after they are complete.Graphics 9/10 - The graphics were really good with a Tron-esque style. Everything was styled beautifully and nothing much wrong to say about it.Gameplay 8/10 - Gameplay was good with nice controls, allowing the user to take car racing to the next level with flying abilities and giving you full control over how the car moves and turns.Sound 10/10 - The soundtrack for this game was amazing. These pieces of music were composed beautifully with a heavy electronic theme and I come back to the game time and time again to listen to the music. The sound effects were also great.Overall 32/40 - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Full disclosure: I backed this game on kickstarter.Distance is basically what you'd get if you put Tron, a racing game, and a rave into a blender that made games.You can drive on the walls, ceilings, and basically anything else. Your car can fly!The controls feel really tight, and even when your car is damaged the physics kind of make it less annoying - having your car sliced in half and driving half a car to the next checkpoint is fairly entertaining.The game is, however, a bit short at the moment. Once you know what you're doing the story mode doesn't take very long, and neither do the other modes. There are generated levels and workshop levels, though, and there's supposed to be a story mode update at some point.Pros:- Cool car mechanics- Lots of modes- Everything glows. You can turn up the glowing if there's not enough glowing.- Replayability, level editor, random level generator- Still updating long after the kickstarter!Cons:- Really short story mode / modes in general

								I never write reviews but... When i was a kid, there was this browser racing game called need for madness. the game is about doing laps and coming in first. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								The more i play distance, the more i feel like it could be THE racing game to pick up. and for an early access title it sure as heck is more polished than other games that share space there.the gist of it is summed up by the trailer and the game's description: you drive a super cool tron car of sorts through various areas in an attempt to get from point a to point b as fast as possible, while trying not to get sliced, smashed, flung off, or nitronic crash into a wall. the latter is silly because you can also drive on walls and cielings, which counts as a stunt (more on that later). you can also fly, but later levels tend to flip flop between letting you fly and not letting you fly, and you can shave seconds off the flying areas if you know how to.and that isn't all. you can cool down your thrusters by doing stunts. don't ask how it works, just roll with it. the controls feel buttery smooth and responsive, though some community made levels will make you think otherwise at times. the music in the game is top notch and i'd gladly toss my cash at Refract or Torcht just to get it through steam.and while the adventure is short and sweet, the replayability comes from the workshop. seriously, go check it out. there's dozens of tracks waiting to be conquered, either alone or in competition with friends and strangers alike. there's  the Stunt mode for those who want to do flips and stuff, or if you want to put it to more use on the courses, Speed and Style is a mode about doing tricks to cut time off the clock. finally, for the ultimate in keepaway, look no further than Reverse Tag. that assumes there's folks hosting that mode, which is often rare. but when it is hosted, it's the perfect blend of sprint, stunt, and king of the hill, with the hill being a ball of sorts that you snag and take with you, but others can also easily snag off you by driving into the ball while you have it.and if you intend to play this on multiplayer, be sure to hop on Distance on Saturdays. correct me if i'm wrong but i think that's the day when folks go outta thier way to host games of Distance multiplayer.EDIT:Californ1a Sep 3, 2015 @ 8:16pm  Yup, every Saturday 2pm-4pm eastern time is our community multiplayer event: http://steamcommunity.com/app/233610/discussions/0/528398719786414266/Pinning this comment to the review. speedy saturdays is a thing, okay?also, figured i'd update this with some developments.Distance now has a Grip button (think Sonic's stomp in later games, but clings to walls and cielings if your wheels are pointed toward them, and slower, and also acts as the increased handling button) and has toned down a certain bug that allowed huge level skipping to the point it could be outright unfun. the trick is still doable, but now it's not capable of skipping entire sections of track.but the biggest improvement is the editor, which is now capable of more things than ever before. you need only look at "Uncanny Valley" for a decent start. granted, it could do that stuff before, but it was limited back then.on a side note, community is active enough that if you DL a map or two via workshop every now and then, you could get a good amount of maps to race on.TL:DR: Distance is a racing game all about going fast, and surviving. loads of community content keep the game fresh enough to last a while, and devs are hard workers, keeping the progress going.EDIT: if you see this review by any chance and get the game, hop onto the discord channel.this also applies to anybody who already owns the game. it's the best way to keep on top of Speedy Saturdays and community events, as well as the community showing off tidbits of what they are working on with the game's editor.oh, and the main levels of the game look like they're going to get prettied up when the adventure mode gets updated content.RIP Broken Symetry, though.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This Distance is a fast and intense action survival racing game, where you drive agens other unique players in advanced atmospheric worlds.Have you ever wanted to be in that Tron legacy world with laser, future and amazing cool music? Well, here is your chance to live it in a car and do alot of driving, jumping, spinning, flying, avoiding insane traps and tracks. The game has a unique design of it's own, where the Tron legacy atmospheric world makes your hearth beat faster. Overall controlls with either keyboard or controller is simple to use, where you get a decent movement of your car. The game allows you to spin, jump, fly and drive with a health bar that might overheat to destroy you. Every map or custom map through workshop has checkpoints that resets/cooling it down.The music is fantastic, and makes you play all day, unfortunately the game has not unlocked the rest of the singleplayer, since it's in progress. The singleplayer campagin on the other hand throws you straight to basic's and into a interesting world of escape.Here is a demo:

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'd honestly say this is one of the most entertaining racing games I've ever played. There's definitely not many games that require you to jump from wall to wall at high speeds while avoiding traps like lasers and saws while listening to fitting music before you've even completed the tutorial. Also the visuals look awesome, but it's not so overdone that you can't figure out what's going on.It's one of those rare games where you can join a server, find one of the best players in the entire game, and still enjoy yourself.To get the most out of it you'll need to play the community levels, since there's not many official levels. It's not a problem though, since a lot of community levels are on par with the official ones, and some are even better (plus the files are usually less than 1mb, so having hundreds of levels downloaded barely takes up any space).Anyway, here's a quick summary:+Looks and feels awesome+Challenging but not frustrating+Music fits perfectly+Hundreds of quality community levels+Procedural track generation (very early stages so will get a lot better)+Doesn't get annoying if you keep failing+Gravity doesn't even matter as long as you're going fast enough+Improved enough from Nitronic Rush to justify buying-Still no AI/ghosts (they'll probably be coming soon, but offline is a little lonely currently)-Some of the dynamic obsticles can feel luck based, which gets annoying if you're going for a fast time-Possibly a little harder to get good at if you have no controller

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok, before you buy this game, go play Nitronic Rush. If you like that you will like this. Distance is a Tron-esqe racing game where you speed along floating roads and fly through obstacles at very high speeds.Gameplay-10/10The gameplay in Distance is absolutely flawless. The controls feel fluid and are very responsive, and I know that I am in control of my car at all times. The gameplay consists of driving along roads at high speeds while dodging obstacles like buzzsaws, lasers, walls, spinning cylinders of death spikes, and so on. While you usually just drive along roads, you also can fly. Everything about the driving and flying is great. There is also a boost system that reminds me of Excite Truck, which was my favorite racing game until I got Distance. Also, if you get cut by lasers, you can still drive with half of your car. That's probably my favorite thing in Distance.Story-N/AThe adventure mode isn't finished yet, so I can't really review it right now.Multiplayer-10/10I haven't encountered any lag in multiplayer yet. You have to get to the finish as fast as possible, trying to beat the other players. However, the other players appear as ghosts and cannot effect your vehicle, making the race into more of a synonomous time trial. Graphics-10/10The graphics remind me of Nitronic Rush, but have a glossy new feel that fits with the atmosphere very well. Overall-10/10For what it is, Distance is a fantastic game. Even though it is essentially a remake of Nitronic Rush, it does everything right. It runs well on lower spec PCs, you can play it on Mac and Linux as well as PC, there's a level editor with workshop support. Just keep in mind that it is a racing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								tl;dr: I had a lot of fun with the game. It was decently challenging, has great visuals, a fun concept, excellent physics, an awesome soundtrack, and even online multiplayer for just being an early access game.Honestly, my only complaints about this game is that the car does not feel heavy enough. I do not know if this was the intent of the developers, but you are able to turn on a dime at high speeds and it feels more like the world is rotating under you rather than you actually turning the car. To go along with this, I would have wished that drifting the car was added into the game, as it would make taking corners at high speeds all the more fun, especially since it could be incorporated into the trick system. Another problem I had was that segments that required you to continually boost, jump, and rotate the car at the same time were difficult because all three of those functions use the right side of the controller and I had a hard time rotating the car once I got it in the air because I had to keep my thumb on the boost button instead of the right thumb stick. I know that this is easily fixed by the fact that other buttons on the controller perform the same functions, like left bumper on an xbox 360 controller activating the boost, but since in the tutorial, it was stated that the A button is used to hold a boost, you could probably see how this would become difficult if others did not know that multiple buttons did the same thing.All in all, the car should behave more like a car, and the tutorial needs to state that other buttons perform the same functions as others, but it was a fun experience playing this game and I hope to see what becomes of it further down the road.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like tron, eye candy, fast paced arcade racing, a good car to look at, dropping acid and a chill mixtape, this IS the game for you. It's a beautiful enveloping experience with the music and racetracks they've put together. Escape into your monitor or span it along 3 monitors or♥♥♥♥♥♥even a large flatscreen, it's one hell of a ride. For me, each level/map/sector has its own unique feel and difficulty.If you play with a controller, it'll be a breeze, however if you're a keyboard user it'll take some getting use to. The controls aren't an instant WTF DO I DO. The game slowly introduces you to new tricks and tips for controlling your sexy little car. The physics glitch out at times for me, when I'm performing wall jumps my car will instantly flip around when I launch off the surface and it'll slide toward the gravitational pull of the map. If you're on a map with a portal and you go backward thru it, you'll get stuck in an infinite loop or sometimes spawn below the map (but you can blow yourself up and try again). The flying mechanics could use a bit of work as well. At times when I deploy the wings off a jump, the car will start rotating and gaining control of it can be tough if you’re on a keyboard. There is a lack of content for this game, but hell, the maps they've got are great and you can finish them in multiple ways with different paths. I've spent some time doing the time trial races and it's really addictive.The multiplayer functionality is good, however I haven't played it much but it is pretty fun (I'll update it as I play more online). There's usually a few (4-6) servers that have games loaded with their own maps. When racing online, there is a time limit, so if you're spectating a new dude you won't be sitting there for hours waiting for him/her to finish. All in all, I pretty sure I missed a few key aspects but nonetheless, it's a very fun game. The graphics are spectacular, the soundtrack is immersive it's a unique experience that I've lost myself in. I really hope the developers make more content for this game, it'd be a shame if they didn't because this software has potential.

content:

Early Access Review
								Distance is still in Beta, but already looks like a complete game. I have not really encountered any bugs so far and it's great fun to play solo. But it's way more fun to play split-screen with friends, you can play literally for hours. I'd highly recommend using a gamepad, it's much better than playing with a keyboard for this game.The music, while it's not what I usually listen to fits perfectly together with the game itself and the atmosphere it creates. One of the things that surprised me is the fact that it runs really well on my second, older pc, which means that for such a beautiful looking game it's really well programmed and not hard on resources at all. The level editor is complex, but great once you get used to it. There's a lot of really cool and interesting tracks in the steam workshop already which I highly recommend checking out. It also makes up for the fact that in the game itself there aren't that many different levels yet.The controls are very good for driving, but flying and walljumps are difficult to get used to in my opinion. It's pretty hard if you use a keyboard and still not easy with a gamepad (in my case an xbox360 controller).I highly recommend Distance for anyone who loves racing games and I still recommend to try it out at a friend's for anyone else.I rate this game at a solid 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Distance is a racing/parkour game where you drive a car which can boost, jump, rotate, and fly, and can even drive on buildings and walls, and it's awesome.While the game is in early access, you might want to ignore that tag; the dev team is active, and they plan to release the game before July this year. The game is pretty stable despite the fact it's in beta, and I haven't really found that many bugs, which is good. Adventure mode isn't complete yet, though, and there's still some refinement of the core gameplay mechancis that needs to be done - but other than that, the game's pretty much complete.There's two main game modes available - Adventure and Arcade.Adventure mode is meant to be a short story mode that also works as a tutorial for the basic game mechanics. It's currently incomplete, but the devs are hard at work on it. They don't want to spoil the full story, so they're keeping their progress on Adventure in their private internal build, and they'll release it to the public in one big update close to launch.Arcade is essentially a collection of different modes. Sprint is the main mode, where you have to get from the start to the end of the level in the quickest time possible. Speed & Style is pretty much the same as Sprint, but doing tricks to earn points will give you a faster time. Then you have Stunt, where you have to do tricks and get the highest score; Challenge, where if you die, you're out; and Trackmogrify, where you enter in a seed and the game generates a track out of that. There's also Reverse Tag in multiplayer (more on that later), which is a free-for-all battle mode where you're fighting for control of a sphere that gradually gets larger over time.While most of the game modes are fun, Stunt mode is pretty dull right now. All you really do is 1) fly in the air 2) do a bunch of spins and flips 3) land to score points 4) GOTO 1 until time runs out. The devs were planning to improve this mode AFAIK but unfortunately it might be scrapped for launch as they don't have a lot of time left now to work on stuff like this. Fortunately, they don't plan on stopping updates after launch, so this mode may return in an improved state afterwards.One thing that's pretty cool about Distance is that this isn't your traditional racer where you're restricted to the track -  this is more of a parkour/platforming game than a driving game. There's no invisible walls blocking you from skipping the track, allowing you to come up with potentionally faster routes. The road is really just a basic guide to the map layout, and being able to deviate from that route and come up with your own is pretty much the entire point. It's not covered well in the tutorial or in the videos above, which is why many players seem to miss this. I like this part of the game a lot, though, so I hope it's covered better in the full release (Actually, in the alpha, which I sadly wasn't a part of, they had tips in the loading screens, one of which was "Feel free to drive on buildings and walls, the roads aren't always the quickest path" - something like that needs to be re-implemented IMO) so more people are aware it and also that newbies won't call out the speedrunners for "cheating" when they're using a skip route.I mostly play Sprint mode, where playing the game itself is really enjoyable. I don't really know how to explain it, though - Jumping between ceilings and floors while dogding giant saws of doom and destruction at high speeds is just a lot of fun for me. I've found the game to be even more enjoyable now that I've learned the skip routes, but I still don't really know how to descibe my enjoyment or why I find it enjoyable. It's just fun.Also included in Distance is a powerful level editor with Steam Workshop support. It's a little tricky to get the hang of, but once you do you can make some really cool stuff. Want to see for yourself? Just check out the workshop. There's a ton of excellent community made levels, so if you get tired of the official levels, check 'em out. Even if you're not tired of the officials, check 'em out. There's some great stuff that's been made, and because of that it's pretty much impossible to run out of content.As I mentioned a bit earlier, this game has a multiplayer mode. You can play splitscreen with friends, or you can join online servers hosted by other players, and even host your own. I haven't personally tried the splitscreen mode, but I have played online. When it comes to the multiplayer in Sprint/Speed&Style/Challenge/Trackmogrify, you're not really racing against the other players - it's basically the same as if you were playing solo, there's just other peole there. Stunt is a bit more competitive as you're trying to get the highest score, and Reverse Tag is only available in multiplayer, because it's basically a battle mode. There's no collision with the other players in online, but there is in splitscreen. To be honest, I like the no collision - it's nice that you can't be knocked out the way by other players. It just fits this game's style of gameplay more, where you're really racing against time rather than other players.I wouldn't recommend this game if you want it soley for the multiplayer, though. It's more of a singleplayer game - plus, the servers are player hosted, and that added with the fact the community is kinda small right now, there tends not to be many servers most of the time. Playing solo is still a blast though, so it's not all bad. At the very least, the small community means that it's unlikely to find someone being a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and from what I've experienced the community is generally positive and helpful.The graphics are pretty nice, but some of the settings can be really intensitive. If you're experiencing low framerates, be sure to turn off realtime reflections, as that's a pretty big performance hog. There's a few bonus effects, like a stylised outlines option that increases saturation and adds an outline to everything, giving the game a slightly more cartoony look. There's also a film noir effect that makes everything black and white, and a cinematic letterbox option that adds black bars to the top and bottom of the screen to give the game a more, well, cinematic feel.The music is awesome, in my opinion. I don't really know much else to say about it as music is entirely subjective, but I just really like it. I'm a fan of electronic stuff, so it's definitely nice to me. It's also catchy and memorable (to me). As I just mentioned, though, music is entirely subjective, so your mileage may vary.There's also VR support, but I haven't tried that myself. I don't own a VR headset.Pros:[+] Very stable for a beta game[+] The game is just really fun, for me at least[+] There's no invisible walls, allowing you to come up with faster routes[+] Powerful level editor[+] Loads of community-made tracks, meaning it's basically impossible to run out of content[+] Splitscreen and online multiplayer[+] VR support[+] Graphics are good[+] Music is greatCons:[-] Stunt mode is kinda boring[-] The level editor is a little difficult to get the hang of at first[-] A small community and player-hosted servers means that there usually isn't many online games available[-] Some graphic settings significantly reduce performanceSo, yeah. I've spent the past ~2 hours on this review, and it's really long, and probably sucks. But still.I also recommend Distance's spiritual predecessor, Nitronic Rush[nitronic-rush.com], which is free and was developed by the same team, among others, as a student project at DigiPen. It's slightly different, but the core mechanics are the same, and it's also pretty fun (though I have not played NR as much as Distance).

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Many games nowadays incorporate some "drive-fast-and-you-don't-fall-off-the-ceiling" mechanic, such as Grip or Distance.Although this mechanic originated around the time of the N64 and the original Playstation, Distance brought it back. This game will send you swirling though various tracks that loop, swoop, spin, and invert. You can stick to the track however it bends, but this won't achieve any record-setting lap times. To be the best, you must leave the track. You can jump onto walls and other obstacles around the world to find the quickest way to the finish line; you can even jump straight to the ceiling if it's not too high above you.That said, many workshop levels are simple roller coasters, requiring you to hold the boost without letting go. How boring, right? The best challenges this game can throw at you will have you jumping from rooftop to interstate overpass to rooftop, and will force you to dodge laser beams and sawblades the whole way. It's a bit like Meat Boy, if you're into that!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Steam early access title Distance shows lots of potential. The self described  "survival racing" feels a bit like Trackmania or Trials but the player is driven less by good runs and more by survival and exploration of their environment. The gameplay is rather deep, far more than I initially expected. Your car has the ability to boost but that's just the start. Wall-riding, mid-air flips, and even flying are often combined to traverse more difficult areas. I've been playing solely the adventure mode and there is much left to explore. I’m looking forward to development of this mode because it seems to hint at a more fleshed out story. A rarity in any racing game. Although, it’s still too early to say what’s under the hood I think it’s worth a ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Distance is a high-octane reaction-based arcade racing game set in what I can only assume to be a computer program with a sick EDM (primarily techno) soundtrack to go with it. A spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, you have only seconds to react to what's in front of you and sometimes not even that much time is given. While sometimes frustrating with no particular payoff other than beating your times, Distance is an exciting game with a cool setting and a great soundtrack. Gameplay: 8.5/10: Distance offers a variety of game modes including a short campaign, arcade sprint, stunt and style races, versus race, and split-screen up to four players. Each gameplay mode, outside of the multiplayer, is mildly lacking in replay value (unless you're a perfectionist and want to get to the top of the leaderboards which I personally could easily see myself attempting). When you enter the multiplayer it becomes an insane race for first, style points, or who can pull off the most wicked stunt. The last time I felt a game play this smooth and fun was Split/Second and that's what this game reminds me of... only if it were set in Tron.Graphics: 8/10: The setting is stunning and the tracks are intense to race on. Neon colours flash past you as you go from 0-250mph in just a few short seconds and the environment keeps up with the action you experience. However, upon closer inspection the environment isn't the most detailed setting, with speed of levels (no laps) and need for concentration aiding in the distractability from the environment itself. The car itself is physically stunning and fun to look at, particularly when you activate the thrusters or flight ability. When it explodes for the umpteenth time, you might be a little remorse at the fact that it constantly splits into the same fractal polygons and rains over the landscape below, but if you can get over that sort of thing you might just find yourself immersed in the reactive world around you, which brings us to our next point.Sound: 9/10: Arguably the star of the game is the notion that the environment reacts to the pumping techno beats and seems to simulate a synesthetic experience. The developers turn sound into visuals which vastly aid in drawing you in to the overall experience. I even found myself reacting and driving to the beat, which for some reason was always perfectly timed to the rest of the level, even if you were to crash with a digitally explosive sound. The soundtrack is genuinely something I find myself coming back to the game to enjoy over and over and over again. The car sounds beautiful and is perfectly matched to its sporty design. I keep returning to the game just to hear the music again and again. I love it that much!Last WordsDistance is a fun game for perfectionists but if you're into unlocks and specials outside of what you purchase, you'll want to look elsewhere. A visual and audible synesthetic experience that draws you in, Distance is the perfect spiritual successor to some of the most fast-paced and intense racing games on the market.8.5/10 - Give it a go, especially if you catch it on sale!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								So It took me a couple days just because once you hit the nightmare stuff it gets moderately frustrating. Best advice is keep calm and pay attention. As difficult as this gets in Distance its key. Theres a way I feel that a Hotas Dualstick controller system would do a lot better with this game than a Keyboard or Xbox 360 controller would. Thats the negatives so far.Positives are quite a few; Take Tron, a light touch of the Horror genre, and the Matrix Highways and the portals from Dystopia and you have Distance. The in game suspense gets quite affective at times. I put down the campaign a few times just to get my head clear from the in game 'stressors' but once I figured out what I was doing its quite fun. I enjoy racing games and this made my engine purr. Refract, I salute the skill put into this so far. Glad to be supporting you know, hopeful for your bright future. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Full disclosure: I backed this game on kickstarter.Distance is basically what you'd get if you put Tron, a racing game, and a rave into a blender that made games.You can drive on the walls, ceilings, and basically anything else. Your car can fly!The controls feel really tight, and even when your car is damaged the physics kind of make it less annoying - having your car sliced in half and driving half a car to the next checkpoint is fairly entertaining.The game is, however, a bit short at the moment. Once you know what you're doing the story mode doesn't take very long, and neither do the other modes. There are generated levels and workshop levels, though, and there's supposed to be a story mode update at some point.Pros:- Cool car mechanics- Lots of modes- Everything glows. You can turn up the glowing if there's not enough glowing.- Replayability, level editor, random level generator- Still updating long after the kickstarter!Cons:- Really short story mode / modes in general

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31
Early Access Review
								Distance is hard to describe so I'll keep this brief. It's nothing like well-known racing games. It is far removed from Wipeout, F-Zero and any other racer that comes to mind. The closest comparison would have to be the Trackmania series, since both titles are all about getting through courses at the fastest time and have truckloads of user-made content. But Distance has deeper gameplay than Trackmania, and isn't about chaotic multiplayer challenges. Distance has more in common with platform games than racing games, and is superficially comparable to the day stages of Sonic Unleashed except that unlike that pile of garbage, Distance is an amazing game.As pointed out by others, if you are unsure of what you are getting yourself into, try Nitronic Rush. A free predecessor to this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
Early Access Review
								"Car Platformer"That's the term I'd use to describe this game.  It's a car platformer.  It's everything great about video game car physics, plus more.  You can jump, you can spin, you can fly, and for the most part you have the freedom to do so whenever you want.One of the greatest things about this game is definitely the freedom.  I don't like when racing games are just a track you have to go fast on.  In this game, though, if you get bored of the normal drive you can jump off the side and drive over all of the buildings and props alongside the track.  Granted, in the game world there aren't going to be a lot of extra places to go, but still.  Navigable scenery is a plus.There's also the unnecessarily entertaining aspect of it where you can continue to drive after having your car sliced in half lengthwise.  That's a bit of an oddball feature that makes for some fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Up until recently one of the most original racing games I've ever played. If you like games like f-zero, track mania and Wipeout then you will probably also like this one.Distance primarly focuses on survival through stunting up, over and under things as you make your way through countless of haphazard areas full of razors and spiked steamrollers. At a certain moment the track starts to rotate horizontally and you even get to drive upside down, straight up and every other angle you can imagine. After a certain while you don't even really know what up and down is anymore, was it not for the arrow on the back of your car that indicates which way down actually is. I do however find myself never really looking at the thing as most community made tracks are so fast and require your full attention. After a while you will be constantly propelling yourself forward with the turbo, jump and angle your car 45 degrees with the thrusters and as soon as you land things might start popping up left and right trying to slice your car in half. You jump on the straight orientated road again and go through a portal which then suddenly leaves you hanging in mid air. The upbeat music has stopped and been replaced for the muffled sounds of you trying to maneuver your car in zero-g. There is also a story, which is something about you being inside of a computer-thingy which is infected by a virus. Which will become apparent in the storyline mode, but not so much right now. This game mainly thrives from the steam workshop integration as there are a lot of custom maps which can leave you playing this game for a long time.

content:

								Ok, so I spent like 10$ on this game, and believe me, last game I've bought for more than 5$ was probably gta4 around 3 years ago. Why did I do that? Simply because I've fallen in love with its prequel, nitronic rush. You can check it out, i think it's 100% free to download.Imo, compared to NR, Distance still lacks these perfectly designed, not-so-trivial campaign levels. In return we get unlimited amount of tracks from the community, and some of them are really beautiful, some quite surprising, some surprisingly creative.Multiplayer works and it's pretty fun, haven't checked splitscreen yet (but it is there).Also, I can't really imagine playing this game without gamepad. My friend played on keyboard and, while he still had really good time with the game, he couldn't micro his movement while freefalling (or in 0G) that well.So, my recomendation: Download NR, try it for yourself if you like it, and then throw some money at these guys, because I think they really deserve it.
